text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Norwegian papers this morning.
- Six members of the motorcycle club Bandidos have refused to be witnesses in the murder trial of a member of a rival biker club. The six claim they may incriminate themselves.

- The teachers' union wants to work with other organisations such as the Norwegian Asthma and Allergy Association to map out atmospheric conditions in classrooms across the country. A recent study shows that poor ventilation in schools has a negative impact on pupils' concentration.

- Norway has withdrawn backing for a hydropower damming project in Chile, Aid Minister Kari Nordheim-Larsen told parliament on Monday. The government has decided to drop its backing despite objections from the Trade Ministry. Norway was to donate 18 million crowns to the project and Norwegian construction and engineering company Kvaerner ASA also was to take part.

- The boards of Christiania Bank og Kreditkasse ASA and insurer Storebrand ASA decided late on Monday to postpone signing a merger agreement between the two. The merger will still go ahead as planned but first the two companies must settle a dispute over preference shares.

- Norsk Hydro ASA is considering buying a fertiliser plant in India and may put in a bid for Mangalore Chemicals and Fertilisers through its Hydro Agri International arm. Sverre Bjerkomp, assistant director in Norsk Hydro's agricultural division, says the company is interested.
- Nako AS will begin production of zirconium at the iron ore port of Narvik in northern Norway. Zirconium is used in fire-resistant materials and in the ceramics industry.

- The management in offshore services company Aker Maritime ASA aims to increase profits from last year's 301 million crowns to around one billion crowns by 2000. The new leadership is also sticking to the goal of doubling turnover to 20 billion crowns in the same timeframe.
